results.title: Living Room
results.brief_description: A catalogue of assorted Sydneysiders pose for the camera “at home”. “Home is where to sleep” - Why do people live where they do? “Home is an extension of your personality” - Do people have a choice in the way they live? What does “home” mean? A photographic mosaic of faces and places, “Living Room” reveals surprising values and attitudes.

results.title: Living room
results.brief_description: A catalogue of assorted Sydneysiders pose for the camera “at home”. A photographic mosaic of faces and places, Living Room exposes the myths surrounding home ownership and the shrinking potential of home ownership and reveals surprising values and attitudes. The program raises questions about the lack of services and isolation associated with outer suburban life. It looks at our treatment of the elderly and the way the nuclear family and the dream of “owning your own home” have shaped our living environment.

results.title: Living outback on a farm
results.creator_credit: Nandor Jenes, Donald Batchelor and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: Presents a view of life on a wheat farm in the Australian outback. Shows farming activities and indicates the necessity of a good water supply. Also shows the nearby town, local school and a picnic.

results.title: Living jazz
results.creator_credit: Jack Gold, John Hall, Paddy Whannel and BFI
results.brief_description: A candid study of the Bruce Turner Jump Band at work, at individual and group practice rehearsal, on tour and as they discuss and arrange their music. Music written and arranged by Bruce Turner. Instruments: Bruce Turner (Alto Sax), John Mumford (Trombone), Johnny Chilton (Trumpet), Colin Bates (Piano), Jim Bray (Bass), Johnny Armitage (Drums). Presented by Doug Dobell and Ken Lindsay.

results.title: Living in the dark
results.brief_description:
Using 2-D animation this short film captures the filmmaker’s childhood experience of an eye injury which not only caused a temporary loss of sight and distortion of vision, but also a sense of fear and loneliness. His father too suffered a similar fate as a child but circumstances were such that he became permanently blind. The story explores family relationships and reflects on life’s unexpected turns. Narrated by Roberto Salvatore.

“Living in the dark” recently won the best cinematography in the 2005 Bondi Short Film Festival in Sydney and was selected for the Electronic Theatre Program at the Graphite 2005 Conference, Dunedin, New Zealand.

results.title: Living in Scotland = The Smiths in Scotland
results.creator_credit: Laurence Henson, Films of Scotland and International Film Associates (Scotland)
results.brief_description: A presentation of the virtues of Scotland and its people. Roots and tradition are still important but change and development is offering new skills and resources to the world. Covers Scotland’s countryside, cities, universities, industries and its sporting opportunities, especially water sports as no part of Scotland is more than 50 miles from the water. Narrated by Bryden Murdoch.

results.title: Living dangerously
results.creator_credit: Richard Mason, Eric Thompson and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Recommends precautions against bush fires in outer-suburban and rural areas. Common fire hazards on suburban properties include undergrowth and scrub on fences, overhanging trees, cluttered spoutings, absence of fly wire on doors and windows to prevent entry of sparks; absence of incinerators and compost heaps to dispose of rubbish. In rural areas the responsibility of the inidividual is greater. The film shows examples of bad fire hazards; crops growing close to buildings; absence of fire breaks; litter strewn over properties. Stresses the need to check spark arrestors on machinery and to maintain fire fighting gear in working condition. In one year, bush fires cost the country fourteen million pounds, a loss which could have been avoided by people being wise before the event. Photography by Frank Bagnall.

results.title: Living colors = Vivre en couleurs
results.creator_credit: Michel Hebert, Francine Desbiens and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Charcoal drawings depict the bleak world of the worker. Pastel drawings illustrate his dreams. Oftentimes, they are dreams created by the media. Are they tailored to his real needs? Or his pocket book? This film comments indirectly on the impact of publicity and its power to develop appetites that cannot be satisfied. An animation film without words.

results.title: Living cells
results.brief_description: Uses the phase contrast optical system to show that living cells are very active structures. Shows how movement can be detected in the cytoplasm of the cells, ranging from a streaming movement of the early cytoplasm to movements by a whole variety of cellular organelles. The cell surface also exhibits movement, and even in the case of multicellularorganisms, movement of the whole cell can be observed. Suitable for upper secondary level.
